supporting_quotes: He secretly joined the Chinese Communist Party in 1942 at the age of 14.
From 1942 to 1945, Qian attended the Utopia University High School in Shanghai.
From 1945 to 1949 he worked at the Ta Kung Pao newspaper.

roles: Secretary of Communist Youth League Committees
supporting_quotes: After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, he was member of the Party Committee and Secretary of the Communist Youth League Committees of the Xuhui, Changning, and Yangpu districts of Shanghai.
Qian left for the Soviet Union and studied at the Komsomol Central School in Moscow from 1954 to 1955.
From 1955 to 1963, he worked as a diplomat in Moscow. He successively served as Second Secretary in the Chinese Embassy... and Counsellor in the Chinese Embassy.

roles: Director of Department of Overseas Chinese Students
Deputy Director General of the Foreign Department
supporting_quotes: He successively served as... Director of Department of Overseas Chinese Students and Deputy Director General of the Foreign Department of the Ministry of Higher Education
During the Cultural Revolution, Qian was persecuted and sent to perform hard labour at a May Seventh Cadre School from 1966 to 1972.
After his political rehabilitation, he served as Ambassador to Guinea (1974–76)
and concurrently Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau (1974–75).
While serving as Director of the Information Department of the Foreign Ministry from 1977 to 1982, he proposed establishing a spokesperson system and became the first spokesperson of the Ministry.
was vice-minister of foreign affairs from 1982 to 1988
China's Foreign Minister from April 1988 to March 1998
Qian became Foreign Minister in April 1988.
Qian was a member of the 12th to 15th CCP Central Committee.
He served as Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Politburo member from 1992 to 2002
He was a member of the 14th and 15th CCP Politburo.
and as Vice Premier from March 1993 to March 2003
He was Vice Premier of the State Council, under Premiers Li Peng and Zhu Rongji, from 1993 until his retirement in 2003.
State Councilors... Qian Qichen P (added)

roles: Order of the Polar Star recipient
supporting_quotes: In November 2005, Qian was awarded the Order of the Polar Star, the highest civilian award of Mongolia, for his contributions to China–Mongolia relations.
his meeting with then British Foreign Secretary John Major in July 1989 was the first such contact.
In October 1989, Qian engaged in low-profile outreach when he attended the annual UN General Assembly in New York

roles: first Chinese diplomat to attend ASEAN Foreign Ministers Meeting
supporting_quotes: He was the first Chinese diplomat to attend an ASEAN event, going to the 1991 ASEAN Foreign Ministers Meeting in Malaysia.
In 1992, he was tasked with traveling to Pyongyang, North Korea to inform Kim Il Sung that China would be establishing formal diplomatic relations with South Korea.
